jorisvandenbossche commented on issue #5402: ARROW-6564: [Python] Do not require pandas for invoking Array.__array__
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5402#issuecomment-532153974
 
 
   Did it now for Array, if the approach seems OK also need to do it for ChunkedArray.
   
   For all dtypes except dictionary type, `ConvertArrayToPandas` already returns a numpy array, so we can call this directly instead of going through `_to_pandas` (wrapping it in a Series) and unpacking the values again. 
   Only for dictionary type, this returns a dict of the indices and dictionary values. I was first thinking of an option to `ConvertArrayToPandas` to convert a DictionaryArray to an dense array, but we can also easily create this dense array afterwards as done now in the PR. 
   However, and in light of https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5398 (cc @wesm), the clear disadvantage of this simpler approach is that the created numpy array is then not in the arrow memory pool (while for all other dtypes they will be). So the option to `ConvertArrayToPandas` might be better?
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

jorisvandenbossche commented on issue #5402: ARROW-6564: [Python] Do not require pandas for invoking Array.__array__
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5402#issuecomment-532806566
 
 
   @wesm thoughts on the "not created in arrow's memory pool" consequence of creating the dense array in python? Or not worth the complexity to try to do this in the C++ conversion code?

wesm commented on issue #5402: ARROW-6564: [Python] Do not require pandas for invoking Array.__array__
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5402#issuecomment-532813975
 
 
   Oh I missed that comment, sorry. Hmm. Might be worth opening an issue but it's unclear what the best option. Casting to Arrow-dense could end up being wasteful (in the case of strings), and implementing the conversion in C++ would be tedious. I'm inclined to let it go for now
